item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell’s Testimony is “Meaningless”
item.description: New revelations in the Epstein files might complicate Ghislaine Maxwell’s bid for clemency. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #trump #epsteinfiles #podcast
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/xcVrlg5rY1o

Transcript

You know how I am about women that do things like this. Let's talk about ghislaine maxwell. Where do you think her case goes from here? I don't think anywhere that she wants it to. Representative Paulina Luna said, “according to the files we saw, ghislaine maxwell was engaged in traffic and rape. I don't think she deserves special treatment. She's a monster.” I hope that there is some world in which Maxwell is moved back to the bad prison, and has to rot in there for the rest of her life. I don't think you can trust a single word that comes out of her mouth. I think her testimony is meaningless. She committed psychological

and physical torture on these girls. I don't know if I really mean this, but to some degree, the person who is recruiting and feeding these girls to Jeffrey Epstein almost feels worse. You know how I am about women that do things like this, where I just think that there is something built into us as the people who bring other people into the world, that you should not be this depraved and sick. And I think that if Trump is reading any tea leaves or Susie Wiles is, she knows that

there can be no kind treatment for ghislaine maxwell, and that no one trusts anything that she says.

item.title: Trump has become “Ineffective”
item.description: Whether he’s posting racist videos, or blaming it on the media, Trump’s old playbook isn’t hitting the same marks anymore. Jessica Tarlov and Scott Galloway discuss, on Raging Moderates.
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/cPt1dcq58Q8

Transcript

The is being called a bit more. >> Over the weekend, President Trump was doing what he's done for years, picking cultural fights. He went after an Olympic skier for expressing mixed feelings about representing the US. I think that skier probably represents most of us right now. Amplified a racist video depicting the Obamas and once again leaned into grievance and division. >> What really stood out to me is how ineffective I feel like he's become. Like he's really lost his fastball. I think they call it the weave that he does, right? where he like finds a way to get a question that he doesn't like and then he goes some other path and

somehow his base plus the extra 10% that voted for him understands what he really meant and all is forgiven and it doesn't really feel like that's happening anymore at least when it comes to these culture war things and on the horrible racist video of the Obamas depicting them as apes that came out Laura Ingram had Caroline Levit on and asked her about it said can you really throw a staffer under the bus and Levit tried this. Oh well, this is a leftist media narrative and she's staring at Laura Ingram. So, it feels like the is being called a bit more. I'm not

predicting some downfall of the Trump administration, but it does feel like he is not hitting his marks in the same way. And he's not able to dangle one trans swimmer in front of people to get them to come over to his side. and that people are actually observing what's going on on the ground and formulating a not so positive view of Trump and co as a result.

item.title: Epstein Scandal TURNS on Trump as Howard Lutnick Gets Caught LYING
item.description:
Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov sit down with Yale leadership scholar Jeff Sonnenfeld to unpack his new book, Trump’s Ten Commandments. They dive into Trump’s racist stunts like posting the recent AI Obama video to his “tribal chieftain” style of centralizing power. Jeff breaks down how Trump bends rules, gets things done outside traditional channels, and uses distraction and propaganda to shift the public's focus.
Prof G also talks with Prof Sonnenfeld about the Resist and Unsubscribe Movement, and what other things that business leaders can do right now to spark collective action.
For more on Scott's Resist and Unsubscribe movement: resistandunsubscribe.com
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov. Follow Prof G, @profgalloway. Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModeratesPod.
#scottgalloway #politics #trump #jessicatarlov #jeffsonnenfeld #trumpstencommandments #venezuela #immigration #elections #democraticparty #democrats #midtermelections #electioninterference #january6th #2020elections #dhs #kristinoem #sarahpalin #trentlott #economicstrike #generalstrike #resistandunsubscribe #resistance #ceo #businessroundtable
Please support this channel by subscribing here: www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPlEda_BRHg

Transcript

Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Scott Galloway >> and I'm Jessica Tarlov. >> We're joined today by Jeffrey Sonninfeld, a longtime Yale leadership scholar and one of Trump's most consistent public critics who has written a new book called Trump's Ten Commandments, also a role model of mine. Jeff is an academic who decided he wanted to have a lot of impact outside of the four walls of his home institution Yale and has just a big footprint and hosts these kind of agoras of uh CEOs and in this moment his voice has never been louder and more resonant.

Uh anyways Jeff thanks very much uh thanks so much for joining us today. >> Uh Scott Jesse it's an honor to to rejoin you. Thank you very much. And talking about having an impact to be on the walls of academia, I can't think of any better role model than you. >> Oh, you guys are adorable. There we go. >> We'll fight. We'll still fight, but about a fellow raging moderate. >> There you go. >> It's a good club. >> Let's bust right into it. Last week, Trump posted a racist AI generated video of Barack and Michelle Obama. How does this kind of provocation fit

into the patterns you identify in Trump's Ten Commandments, your new book? >> Well, thanks so much. And we talk about in there is as various elements such as divide and conquer, as you know, in terms of how he divides uh business communities and and and influential uh institutions uh so that they can be subject to different tyades of v vindictiveness. Uh, and there's a little bit of that at play here, but in particular, we have a chapter in there called the wall of sound that u that Scott, even you are perhaps too young to

remember, but I bet you do. As the Phil Spectre, very controversial uh bad guy record producer who uh uh was known for having so many instruments blaring at once in this the same note, same harmony, is that it's a it's a a kind of a a distraction device that Trump has. Some people call it the the shiny object. Uh some people will uh you know call it the wag the tail and and and applying it to Venezuela, but it's a way of uh of distracting no doubt about it that this is bigoted, hostile and racially offensive to put it mildly. Uh

th those cartoons were not some subtle dog whistle. It was screaming racial uh venom at at the top of lungs. However, wherever he comes out on racial issues, he's using it strategically. Even though it comes out angry as as a midnight post, which supposedly some other staffer was on his Truth Social account at the exact second at midnight, but nonetheless, people think wrongly that these are impulsive decisions, these are uh deliberate strategic devices. The Venezuela attack, however you feel about

drug trafficking, the idea of Chinese and Russian ships surrounding Venezuela, that didn't work. and blaming the oil industry execs when they to a person told me they had nothing to do with it, no interest in it. Is that he just, you know, looking for ways to change the subject off of Epstein, affordability, healthc care issues, uh that he tried the Venezuela of Greenland the week after that. There's nothing particularly ownorous or threatening that we had to go in to start to threaten the possible military and economic sanctions for Greenland. uh the the the seizing these um election ballots uh out of South

Falton County. These are desperate efforts to change the subject from domestic largely domestic issues he doesn't want to talk about and using race is always a last resort of scoundrels and he's not above that. >> Before I just toss it to Jess, I'd love to know based on your book and your research here, how do we of the ten commandments of Trump, how do we break the tablets? I think a lot of us are frustrated at what is seen as fairly anemic push back by Democrats or a lot of us are just frustrated like what do I

do? Do you have any thoughts on what the most effective push back and the format and the mediums and the message? >> I'm so glad Jesse if we take the next two hours to talk about that great question. It's a big one. >> I'm in it to win it. You guys go. That's the essence here is u we have these these 10 issues that everything all the power centralized through him. He uses a sleeper effect which is a a propaganda device that was actually studied here at Yale we're sorry to say in the 40s and 50s trying to learn from what uh the third Reich was doing in the 30s is

repeating false information repeat over and over. There's a lot of devices in there that you would recognize as manipulative mass communications tools and strategy devices. The most important thing is though what you asked which is instead of labeling him as as an autocrat as as a demagogue or as a as a psychotic sociopath or all the different labels that different disciplines throw out there which which however accurate they may or may not be they don't tell us what to do and how to respond to it. It's like you don't you don't make any progress calling an alcoholic a drunk. >> Getting past the fingerpointing and

trying to figure out what we do about it. It's collective action. That's how you take down a bully. Uh we have seen it happen successfully in August of 2017 after the tragic killing of an innocent young woman peaceful protester in Charlottesville in August 2017. Uh Trump went on the air that was a Friday night on the air Saturday and made a a very underwhelming statement of sympathy and then somebody whomever Steven Miller I don't know advised him to go back into it again the next day Sunday and came out with the equivocation of the white nationalist who murdered this woman being you know good on both sides with

the quivocation statement that led Ken Fraser of MC one of four black CEOs leading a Fortune 500 firm at the time to say I've had it I'm out and he told his board you do what you want I can't speak for MC I'm speaking for me and the board fortunately backed is there's a slight delay the next day and we started calling through to all different offices of corporate America and that led to a mass exodus a stampede left the business advisory councils to this day the business roundt never made a statement on this but that was a grassroots exit that made a huge difference they walked away from Trump and they didn't come back until in 2021

and January uh there's other than Elon Musk there's no support in the US business community on the trade front we saw the national association of manufacturers It was a pretty much arc right-wing group that was not interested in civil rights issues, wasn't interested in the Vietnam War, wasn't interested in environmental concerns, and that's why the business roundt was formed as a reaction to them of all things that that showed collective action. Uh, believe it or not, we actually unified 700 college and university presidents to take a stand midappril last spring after Harvard and Colombia and other schools were being

sequentially attacked. We saw the anemic response of law firms and thought, well, can't university world do better. Despite the the nonsense uh the BS of these institutional neutrality statements, these college presidents, university presidents uh overrode their own boards of trustees and came out with a very strong collective set of statements and those edicts stopped. So, it's collective action that does it. But it can't just be the CEOs. I asked the CEOs, why aren't we hearing from more of you? and they say, "Where are the clergy?" Until Minneapolis, if your life depended on it, you couldn't name me

five clergy, interfaith clergy, linking arms the way they did in the 60s and 70s to take a stand. Even now, with the exception of Minneapolis, we don't see the trade unions speaking out. We don't see the professional associations and and again, we talk about the campuses. Uh these voices which were very important in the 60s to be across sectors are somewhat muted now. Jos >> um I that was all really interesting and now I have many directions that I want to go in but I I want to go back to something that you said in your first answer and you mentioned Epstein which is the kind of topic dour right now and

as we're recording this commerce secretary Howard Lutnik is testifying um before the Senate uh he had a relationship with Jeffrey Epstein he claimed publicly that he didn't talk to him after 2005 Senator Van Holland kind of has him dead to rights on that and I want to play this clip and then get your response as to what you think Trump's leadership style at this moment is going to lead him to do. So, let's look at that. I >> I think you understand the root of concern here. It's the way you described very emphatically your first encounter

with him in his apartment, said you were disgusted, would never have any contact with him again. Did you in fact make the visit to Jeffrey Epstein's private island? >> I did have lunch with him as I was on a boat going across on a family vacation. My wife was with me as were my four children and nannies. I had another couple with they were there as well with their children and we had lunch on the island. That is true for an hour and we

left with all of my children with my nannies and my wife all together. We were on family vacation. We were not apart to suggest there was anything unoured about that in 2012. I don't I don't recall why we did it. But >> Mr. Secretary, again, >> so I just want to note this is after Jeffrey Abstein is a registered sex offender. Letic said that he didn't interface with him after 2005. Based upon what you know about Trump's view and his leadership style, how do you think that he's going to handle having a

cabinet secretary caught in this kind of lie and the attention that it brings to the administration? >> Well, Trump doesn't ever apologize as we see with the racial situation. And we had somebody uh Trent Lot, if anybody remembers that name, who was the Senate majority leader, Republican Senate Majority Leader, made a a quote unquote off-color joke back in I don't think 2004 or so, saying that um if only STM Thurman had won in 1948 for president. That was enough to force his resignation. We saw people such as Wilbur Mills, the chairman of the Ways

and Means Committee on a indiscretion doesn't compare to these things or u or Dennis Hasser, N Gingrich, uh the Bob Livingston, former Republican speakers of the House all had to resign for things. There was shame not that long ago. We saw shame still matter and and what's happened here is atrocious. There's we have a chapter in there on on how he moves away from losers. uh that he's decided that Giuliani and whomever else uh uh Sarah Palin are too much of a liability for him. He me he doesn't have a a two-way loyalty. He doesn't mind

cutting things off. The challenge here, which is such a good question, Jesse, is we would predict from that chapter that he would drop Lutnik. I mean, a lot of CEOs tell us after they shake hands with Howard Lutnik, now they want to wash their hands. I mean, obviously they feel soiled. This guy's reputation is in the sewer. He has overtly lied. You know, on that clip you showed, it doesn't demonstrate whether or not he actually perjured himself under oath, but we do know that he said repeatedly in recently to the media that, as you pointed out, was 2005, he had no more contact with that disgusting person. And now we see

that he not only built a house next door to him, uh, but he was investing in businesses for years later. He he stayed in contact for 12 years past. He told us he'd stopped all contact. and apparent if you take a look at the emails suggesting there was a trip to the island. We don't actually see the trip. We see the before and after. I don't know. But is that if he takes the move on Lutnik and pushes him out, which he should, does that start the quote unquote proverbial slippery slope where all the indiscretions of Hegsth and and others start to spiral out of control? I think it's possible that um he could

lose Lutnik. Lutnik is not popular on the cabinet. Obviously, this would make Secretary of Treasury Scott Besson's day to get rid of Lutnik and maybe take Bill Py with him. >> I was going to say I think he wants PY out out too. >> Yeah, they'd like to send those guys back to the bowling alley. I mean, this is a lot of CEOs say Howard Lutnik is the Fred Flintstone of finance and and that these days would be a compliment. He's bringing nothing but shame. But the thing is with Trump himself with 38,000 redacted mentions uh in this report, how

does he stop it from spreading? It's a great question. We would predict that he'd figure out a way of getting Lutnik out of there. U but u he will first try for a while the denial just like he said just a few months ago that this is a Democratic hoax. There's nothing to the Epstein files after on the campaign trail saying this is the this is the answer to the Democrats uh pedophilia uh fraud. >> Yeah, I should check Poly Market for the odds that we strike Iran tonight because I know that's usually the go-to distraction. Um >> you're exactly right. It's something

like that. Maybe they they need to to worry about this in in in Montaco or Likensstein or or Luxembourg, you know, or some other area of great concern to Donald Trump that he'll raid to distract us as a major concern or what blue city he's going to come after. >> Well, I want to just say what you said about a shameless administration is so important and run by a man who doesn't feel shame. So, as regular people on the ground trying to navigate this, how do you think the American people, and this links obviously to what Scott is doing

with uh people unsubscribing from these services, companies that don't seem to be taking a stand at anything against the administration, but how do you think that we can create an environment where some sense of shame comes back to our elected officials? Obviously, winning elections is part of that. Um, but in the day-to-day, >> well, uh, here's the challenge is people watching CNN or MS Now or reading The Atlantic and trottling to themselves, "This guy's such a loser. He's so stupid." U, just because Trump uh, often

appears uh, convincingly ignorant doesn't mean he's stupid. He's dumb as a fox. He has incredible street savvy. people who keep predicting his demise ever since, you know, he attacked the Pope and and John McCain and and people who are PSWs that he considered losers. All these third rails that he's taken on and survived, uh they need to recognize that it's going to take something more. The collective action is important part. Uh but we also saw that uh this disengagement that Scott talks about is part of an even larger spirit of voice.

When I talk to CEOs about taking a stand right now, they're afraid. You know, he look who he's attacked. He's attacked Jamie Diamond, the most feared and revered finance in the world, the CEO of JP Morgan. Uh he's attacked Brian Moyahan of Bank of America. He's he's attacked David Solomon at Goldman Sachs, stepping away from finance. He's a attacked Coca-Cola. What could that Coke is the most universal expression uh globally as Scott knows as a great marketer? Then the expression okay is expression Coke. He's taken on Coca-Cola. He's taken on Delta Airlines. He's taken on um Harley-Davidson.

Harley, what could be a more iconic American brand? That their very mascot is uh the symbol is is the u is the bald eagle. Their customers, the riders lead slightly MAGA. their workforce slightly anti-MAGA. The CEO just tries to pilot it down the center of the road because of reciprocal trade barriers from Europe against Trump. Harley had to shut down its plant because all of its bikes were made in in not just North America, made in the US. They had to shut down a plant in Kansas City, open one in Thailand. Trump took that as a personal offense and said, "Don't buy Harley the stock plumber." They fired the CEO, Matt

Levitage. Check it out. So, you know, that's a cautionary tale to CEOs. You can't act alone. But like Ken Frasier did is you can stimulate, you can spark as uh the last line in in in Ipsson's great play enemy the people is the strongest person in the world. He actually said the strongest man but he meant the strongest person in the world is the person who can stand alone is somebody who can set a model. We need that but we also need that collective action. What else do we need? The CEOs who want to do something say you know we're not oligarchs. only three to five percent are the people that that Scott was one of the first to go after in

terms of this oligarchic control of tech titans is 97 98% of them are hired hands they're salaried employees some of them overly salaried you know maybe some too well paid but still they they say we have to respond to constituents but who do they hear from they hear from red state treasurers they hear from red state attorneys general saying our pensioners money in our state we want you to either be silent or be you know mildly somewhat pro MAGA the where the blue state attorneys general have been weirdly quiet quiet not to mention as we mentioned the clergy everybody else so we need to have that kind of pressure

and as Scott talks about and Jesse was just echoing the consumer boycotts are just one part there's a lot of pressure that goes on whether or not because oddly enough a lot of consumer goods companies are not always the first to move these days but they do feel the sensitivity of public pressure so going after consumer goods companies matters a lot >> jeeoff you know this you're a role model of mine we share a lot we're both academics we both want to have and enjoy having impact outside of the classroom. were both Jews. And I don't know, I I see a lot of parallels not with Nazi

Germany, but with late stage Weimar Republic Germany that I find very alarming what's going on in the US right now. And where I I don't agree, I don't think Trump gives a about the clergy or unions who he listens to are the people that you convene at a greater scale and density than anyone in the world. I've been to your CEO events. You bring together more powerful CEOs in a room than anyone in the world. I think more than Davos in terms of concentration of CEOs of Fortune 500.

And I'm empathetic to the notion that nobody wants to go first because if you go first, a good autocrat smacks you back. You do have an obligation to your shareholders. So, everyone is reticent to go first. I get that. What we need is someone at the center of these Fortune 500 CEOs who convinces them to take collective action. I can't think of anyone who is more ripe, capable, and well positioned to be that leader than you. What do we need to do? What is required to help Jeffrey

Sonnenfeld get 10, 50, 100 of the Fortune 500 cos, the people that the president listens to? He's only backed away from threats to annex Greenland or tariffs when he hears from the markets or CEOs. You're their Yoda. You're their whisperer. What is it going to take for Jeffrey Sonnenfeld to get collective action from Fortune 500 CEOs? >> Scott, we have done it repeatedly. uh for example uh the the 2020 elections that Trump says were fraudulent. was the

absentee ballots leaned heavily uh towards Biden whereas in in person polling was leaning towards Trump and that's because the people who believed in science were less likely to go uh to the polling places because of co at the time uh count after count 64 court decisions endless audits and recounts and things and we convened the top 100 CEOs on 12 hours notice to come out with a a stand congratulating the winners to demand a speedy transfer of hour. Uh that made a big difference on the roll backs in 17 states on these crazy voting

rights restrictions. We brought them together repeatedly. So three or four times we we brought these CEOs together when it when it really mattered. They will. But they also hear from their constituents. You're right. Trump doesn't care what the clergy have to say or he wouldn't have made such a fool of himself at the national prayer breakfast on Friday. But he but those CEOs care what the clergy. They care what the trade unions. They care what the investors, what the community activists, what the campus voices, they care about all these stakeholders. It was just five, six years ago they're talking about stakeholder capitalism. Well, where are those stakeholders? They're

sitting home eating their steak, watching TV and chroling expecting Trump's imminent demise, and they're wrong. They have to speak out. Then the CEOs will respond. CEOs just can't say, "Well, it's my patriotism, my personal values, my ethics." No. Unless they're one of those handful of oligarchs, they're a custodian of other people's resources. they need to hear from those other people. As um Toqueville said when he came to the country in 1840, he wrote democracy in America, a French jurist. He wondered why do our laws work. He said it's not because of the tightness of the laws. It's the looseness of the laws. They adapt the circumstances, but for them to work, what Toqueville said,

it involves trust in the community. That means business leaders, he specified business leaders and other leaders of the community have to certify the truth. Toqueeville called it social capital. People think that's a newly invented term. Toefield coined it in 1840 and he said social capital is as important as financial capital. These people are the pillars. They are the most respected. Sadly, legislators, federal, state, local, the media, academia, clergy have all lost standing in American society. Business leaders are still ascendant. My CEO in the Alamman trust surveys just

last week and do still the strongest, most trusted voice as my CEO. We do need to hear from them. We have to give them license to speak for us speaking up and telling them to speak. They work for us. Tell them so. Jeffrey Sonnenfeld is a longtime Yale leadership scholar who has written a new book called Trump's Ten Commandments and I would propose is the leader we need right now. Uh, Professor Sonnenfeld was really happy to hear from you and appreciate your time. Well, >> thank you very much, folks. Thanks, Jesse. Thanks, Scott.

>> Thanks.

item.title: Trump Tariffs Cost U.S. Families $1,000
item.description: With wealth inequality hitting French Revolution levels, the U.S. economy may be at its breaking point. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #trump #economy #politics
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/PjmPZJ0JlXU

Transcript

What do you think Americans think about the Trump economy? >> They don't like it. Everybody doesn't like it. I mean, maybe the richest of the rich. Doesn't matter the survey, the pollster. Tax Foundation just came out uh with their appraisal of the Trump tariffs. American households paid $1,000 more last year because of the tariffs. I think that people know what's up. >> According to NPR and the Maris PBS News survey, 71% say the income gap between the richest and middle class in the US is increasing. In addition, the genie coefficient which measures I guess variance and it's applied to wealth.

Everyone has the same would be zero. If one person owned everything, that'd be 100. When the French Revolution happened, the genie coefficient was somewhere between 80 and 85. Today in America, the genie coefficient around wealth is 83. We are literally at the point where revolutions happen. >> It's pretty bleak.

item.title: “I hate to break it to you”, but elite colleges matter.
item.description: Private school tuition is hitting record highs. Is it worth it Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #politics #podcast #economy
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/32X3nD3fLYw

Transcript

Private school tuition in New York City has officially crossed jaw-dropping territory. Several elite schools are now charging more than $70,000 a year, more than many top colleges as families flee a struggling public system embraced from major changes under the new mayor. By the way, there's a lot of research showing the best school for your kid is the closest, public or private, and reinvest that commute time back into study, sleep, play, time with parents. But let's say you send them to their local public school and you were wrong. They don't get as good an education. And to be clear, the average public school in America spends $15,000. The average private school 75. So over the course of

12 years, $720,000 funneled through an education system. It's going to pay off for your kids as evidenced by the SAT where lower income kids score 150 points less than middle- inome kids. And then hold your hats. Upper income kids score 250 points higher than middle class kids because for 12 years they've had another $60,000 in education, tutoring, counseling. If you took that $70,000 and you were disciplined and you sent it to Vanguard every year and send them to the local public schools, say you [ __ ] up. They don't get into an elite school. They don't get into an elite college. Okay, people will say elite college

doesn't matter. Yeah, it does, folks. I hate to break it to you, it does. And any parent telling you college doesn't matter anymore just found out their little Susie got a 22 on the ACT and is trying to make himself feel better. But say, fine. Okay, we put that $72,000 a year aside. The kid doesn't get into an elite school, doesn't get out of the gate strong, can't get a house. We [ __ ] up sending them to public school. If you had taken that $72,000 and over 12 years were disciplined about putting it in an index fund and the market went up 9% at 35, you can ease your guilt and your kids' pain by giving them $4.5

million.

item.title: Pam Bondi IMPLODES Over Epstein Bombshell as Shutdown LOOMS
item.description:
Immigration enforcement suddenly halts in Minneapolis as Democrats push to disrupt ICE funding and shut down DHS unless major reforms happen. At the same time, Pam Bondi’s House hearing turns into a four-hour Epstein showdown — with survivors in the room and Democrats accusing the DOJ of stonewalling. Jessica Tarlov and Aaron Parnas (@aaronparnas1) break down whether Bondi just handed the opposition a powerful midterm talking point. Cracks are also forming inside the GOP. House Republicans defy Trump on tariffs, triggering primary threats and raising a bigger question: is the party truly starting to break ranks — or is this just symbolic rebellion? And with 130,000 jobs added in January and unemployment ticking down to 4.3%, is the labor market shaking off the trade war drama? Plus: RFK Jr.’s pivot from vaccine skepticism to “healthy eating,” Pelosi’s endorsement of Jack Schlossberg, Prince Andrew’s reported settlement money, and an Olympic controversy that has everyone talking.
Pam Bondi’s disastrous testimony Cracks in the GOP’s support for tariffs The end of immigration enforcement in Minneapolis
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov Follow Prof G, @TheProfGPod Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModerates
Subscribe to our YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kds492UqO3I

<Untitled Chapter 1>

Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Jessica Tarliff. >> And I'm Aaron Parnes. >> And in today's episode, we're discussing Pam Bondi's disastrous testimony, cracks in the GOP's support for tariffs, and the end of immigration enforcement in Minneapolis. If you aren't already, please make sure to subscribe to our YouTube page to get up-to-date coverage. All right, Aaron, let's get into it.

Pam Bondi’s disastrous testimony

This week's House hearing with Attorney General Pam Bondi turned into an allout Epstein match as she stonewalled Democrats for four hours and refused to apologize for the DOJ's handling of the files, even with survivors in the room. Let's watch a clip. >> How many of Epstein's co-conspirators have you indicted? >> You showed it. You I I find it. >> How many have you >> Excuse me. I'm going to answer the question. >> I answer my question. >> No, I'm going to answer the question the way I want to answer the question. Your theatrics are the way I asked it. Chairman Jordan, I'm not going to get in the gutter with these people. >> You can let her filibuster all day long,

but not on our watch. >> Not on our time. No way. And I told you about that, Attorney General, before you started. >> YOU DON'T TELL ME. >> OH, I did tell you because we saw what you did in the Senate. >> Lawyer, not even a lawyer. >> Was the president aware of Secretary Lutnik's ties to Epstein when he chose him to lead the Department of of Commerce? >> Chris Men was a border patrol agent. >> Okay. which is annoying. >> Maybe it'll be different when it's [clears throat] Trump International. Okay. What was Should we calm down about? >> Not much. >> Yeah, it's pretty bad. Okay. >> All right. >> It was great to see you. I'll see you next week. >> See you next week.

Transcript

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnik is testifying before the Senate. Did you in fact make the visit to Jeffrey Epstein's private island? I did have lunch with him as I was on a boat going across on a family vacation. This guy's reputation is in the sewer. He has overtly lied. On that clip you showed, it doesn't demonstrate whether or not he actually perjured himself under oath, but we do know that he said repeatedly into recently to the media that as you pointed out was 2005. He's had no more contact with that disgusting person. And now we see that he not only built a house next door to him, but he was investing in businesses for years later.

He stayed in contact for 12 years past. He told us he'd stopped all contact. Based upon what you know about Trump's view and his leadership style, how do you think that he's going to handle having a cabinet secretary caught in this kind of lie and the attention that it brings to the administration? If he takes the move on Lutnik and pushes him out, which he should, does that start the quote unquote proverbial slippery slope where all the indiscretions of Hegsth and others start to spiral out of control? I think it's possible that um he could lose Lutnik. Lutnik is not popular on the cabinet. A lot of CEOs tell us after they shake hands with Howard Lutnik now, they want to wash their hands. I mean, obviously, they feel soiled.

item.title: Trump’s racist post was a “desperate effort”
item.description: Yale School of Management’s Jeffrey Sonnenfeld joins Jessica Tarlov and Scott Galloway to discuss how racist AI-generated content fits into a larger pattern of political “commandments”. #trump #podcast #politics
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/2JMYeuR---U

Transcript

Using race is always a last resort of scoundrels and he's not above that. >> Last week, Trump posted a racist AI generated video of Barack and Michelle Obama. How does this kind of provocation fit into the patterns you identify in Trump's Ten Commandments, your new book? >> Those cartoons were not some subtle dog whistle. It was screaming racial uh venom at at the top of lungs. However, wherever he comes out on racial issues, he's using it strategically. Even though it comes out angry as as a midnight post, people think wrongly that these

are impulsive decisions. These are uh deliberate strategic devices. He tried Venezuela of Greenland the week after that, seizing these election ballots out of South Fton County. These are desperate efforts to change the subject from largely domestic issues he doesn't want to talk about. looking for ways to change the subject off of Epstein, affordability, healthc care issues, and using race is always a last resort of scoundrels. And he's not above that.

item.title: Why This Govt. Shutdown Might be LONG
item.description: Aaron Parnas and Jessica Tarlov discuss why Dems shouldn’t cave on the government shutdown this time around. #politics #ice #podcast
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/cK0NF3cozdQ

Transcript

Donald Trump took his most popular issue and flushed it down the toilet. >> There's going to be a government shutdown uh for a little while. >> Oh, you think that? >> 100%. I think it's going to last through Trump's State of the Union. I think it's going to be a prolonged shutdown. And I think that it's worth a prolonged shutdown because I don't think that any new money should be going to ICE in this time. I never liked the moniker abolish ICE. I actually preferred abolish Trump's ICE. Just this version of the department in the sense that like I don't think this version of the department should exist. I think that violent criminals who are here illegally should not be here, but your average

everyday undocumented immigrant who is here contributing to society should be here if they want to be. There should be a pathway to citizenship. I can go on my soap box all day, but I think that we'll see what happens in Minneapolis. I just worry that they're going to draw down in Minneapolis and then what? We're going to go to Springfield, Ohio, right? Like we're going to go to Philly. Where are we going to go next?

item.title: Pam Bondi Has No Decency

This week's house hearing with Attorney General Pam Bondi turned into an allout Epstein match. >> Excuse me. I'm going to answer the question. >> And I told you about that, Attorney General before you started. >> You don't tell me. >> Oh, I did tell you because we saw what you did in the Senate. >> Lawyer, not even a lawyer. >> This is not a game, Secretary. >> I'm attorney general. My apologies. I couldn't tell. So, I was on an airplane while this hearing was going on and consuming these clips from the sky. And I feel like if anyone was watching my face, like they would never figure out that I was

watching a hearing cuz I thought it was like some insane movie where I was like, "Oh, no, she didn't." And then like, "Oh, is that really happening?" And then almost crying when she wouldn't even turn to look at the survivors, which seems like the lowest level of basic decency. What were your big takeaways? Number one, she didn't answer a single question about the Epstein files or really anything that Democrats threw her way. I think number two, and people may be mad at me for this, but I thought that the Democratic plan going into it was horrible. Yes, you have a very combative witness, but also like do better in terms of cross-examining her.

The real losers in the hearing are the survivors. Those are the ones who lost.

the Ukrainian skeleton racer who was disqualified from the Winter Olympics after refusing to remove a helmet honoring 24 of the 500 plus Ukrainian athletes killed in the war. item.title: The Failed Attempt to Silence Stephen Colbert
item.description: After CBS pulled his interview with Texas Rep. James Talarico from the air, Stephen Colbert had some words for Trump’s FCC Chair Brendan Carr. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss corporate media “bending the knee” to the Trump administration, on Raging Moderates.
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/CYwQDpT6Ah4

Transcript

James Talarico, the charismatic Texas state representative, was scheduled to be interviewed by Stephen Colbert on his show this past Monday night. But at the last minute, CBS told the hosts that the interview would not air and that he shouldn't talk about it on the show. Colbert doesn't appear to be complying. He called out FCC Chair Brendan Carr by name. On January 21st of this year, a letter was released by FCC chairman and smug bowling pin Brendan Carr. Well, sir, you're chairman of the FCC, so FCC you. It appears to be another example

where corporate media is responding to the Trump administration’s policies, or... desires, if you will. They're just ghoulish at this point, and they're more interested in the tiny fights, I feel like, than the big ones. Or maybe they feel like if they do the tiny fights, then we won't notice the big ones. But I feel like this is just going to be another L for them. It's a really bad look for these networks to constantly be bending the knee, and you don't get anything in return. That is the lesson we have seen thus far. You are not better off by doing this. You're just losing money

or brand value, which translates into money. I think it's important we're clear on what actually happened here. Paramount is trying to get regulatory approval for a merger, and the FCC chair sends a letter, not even a rule, but a letter about equal time, which is a ruse for censorship. And CBS lawyers immediately spike a guest booking on a show. That has three months left on the air anyway. That's not regulatory or legal caution. That's a protection payment. And here, in terms

of that payment, the currency is editorial independence, and they spent it on the cheap. Meanwhile, Colbert does exactly the right thing, defies the order. Talks about the defiance on air, posts the interview on YouTube, and the interview that CBS tried to kill will get more views in any interview they actually aired this month. They're not silencing speech, which is their objective. They've accidentally turbocharged it. The folks working on the Talarico campaign for Senate are like, “who do we send the flowers to?”

item.title: Censoring Stephen Colbert BACKFIRES
item.description:
Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov break down how censoring Colbert backfired on CBS — after Texas state Rep. James Talarico’s scheduled appearance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert was abruptly pulled off the air. Is this corporate media caving to Trump-era pressure — and is Paramount the real loser? Then: the DOJ says it’s done releasing the Epstein files — but reports suggest the public has seen just 2% of them. If that’s true, who’s still exposed, and why is the department claiming mission accomplished? Plus: a DHS funding showdown is underway in Congress. With ICE funding already secured, and public trust in government near historic lows, which party blinks first?
Talarico-gate How the DOJ has only released 2% of the Epstein files and what’s still hiding The future of ICE
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov Follow Prof G, @TheProfGPod Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModerates
Subscribe to our YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SbWeHOAKHPc

<Untitled Chapter 1>

Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Scott Callaway. >> And I'm Jessica Tarliff. >> In today's episode, we're going to discuss Taller Rico Gate, how the DOJ has only released 2% of the Epstein files, and what it's still hiding, and the future of ICE. Uh, if you haven't already, please make sure to subscribe to our YouTube page to get up-to-date coverage on everything happening. All

Talarico-gate

right, let's get into it. James Terico, the charismatic Texas state representative, was scheduled to be interviewed by Steven Colbear on his show this past Monday night, but at the last minute, CBS told the host that the interview would not air and that he shouldn't talk about it on the show. Colbear called out FCC Chair Brendan Carr by name. It's another case where corporate media is responding to Trump administration policies. Jess, what's your take here? >> Paging Ted Cruz. Remember how Ted Cruz was the voice of reason when this happened with Jimmy Kimmel just a few months ago? It feels like forever ago, but it was just a few months. They're

obviously, you know, trying to run the same playbook. They attempted this with The View. Taller Rico was on the View um a couple of weeks ago. And you know, it's disappointing that corporate media keeps bending the knee. Corporate law firms, corporate me, anything with corporate in front of it uh seems to not be doing that well, finding their spine in the Trump era. But I thought it was very well handled by Co Bear. And you know, I was one of the millions of people that immediately clicked that YouTube link and listened to the interview uh this morning as I was

walking down here to record this podcast. And you know, it gave them a bit of a badass sheen that uh two kind of arguably, you know, dorky guys like Steven Colbear and James Tarico wouldn't normally have. But I, you know, I think it's just another lesson in how things go during the Trump era. it will continue down this path and people need to continue to find their voice against it. I just like don't understand though why the Trump administration keeps

committing these own goals, right? Cuz it's just going to drive people. I mean, I was going to watch James Terico no matter what, but there are a lot of people who wouldn't normally tune into Colbear who don't particularly care about James Terrier or even know what's going on in the Texas Senate primary on the Democratic side who are now more interested in him. So, doesn't it just completely defeat the purpose of what they were trying to do in getting Terico off the air? >> I can't imagine if there were a conspiracy here, it would be that the biggest funer of Terico or the biggest uh proponent of

the Tal Rico campaign, planted someone at the FCC and convinced them to do this. >> Should we make Brendan Carr for Terico t-shirts? >> This is all of a sudden. So, first off, let's talk about the losers. Paramount CBS spiked a 60 Minutes story. Appears to have By the way, Anderson Cooper announced he's leaving 60 Minutes. >> I saw that's so sad. 20 years. >> Oh, I I'm I'm name dropping right now. I know I know Anderson and I text him like smart move. He's He spent 20 years

there. It's built his brand. He did a great job and leaving on his terms absolutely the right thing to do and it sends a very strong signal. And quite frankly, if there was an enterprising producer could probably call half the producers at 60 Minutes and raise $50 million from a from a Democratic uh billionaire and say, "I'm going to start something called um, you know, 3600 seconds and basically re, you know, reimagine 60 Minutes like it used to be." I think that's a big opportunity. But it Paramount CBS keeps saying, "Oh,

we're no longer an independent news network. We are the propaganda arm of the Trump administration and it's just not going to serve them well." And as evidence of that, the first week that they had their new anchor for CBS News, their viewership went from 5 million a night to 4 million. Now, I will see say this, it's keeping CBS in the news, which is literally going from irrelevant to less than irrelevant. So they're in the news a lot, but for the wrong reasons. And uh so Paramount CBS, huge loser here, no doubt about it. The Trump administration cementss the notion they

don't believe in a free press, which only massively juices the viewership of this interview. Uh the other loser, unfortunately, through no fault of her own, is Representative Crockett, who Tarico just got this wind in his sales where he's seen as this resistance fighter that everyone is so scared of. The Empire has put out all sorts of hits on him which makes him look like a bigger threat. And obviously Cole Bear is an enormous winner here because he continues to look like, you know, his hat is just starched bright white. But this was effectively, you know, this

wasn't censorship. Um, this was amplification. Brendan Carr just made Terico famous in Texas. Terico could have raised 20 or $30 million. it wouldn't have done as much for his campaign as Brendan Carr just did. >> It's also an interesting contrast. You know, we just had the Munich Security Conference and the right-wing and Republican party here is always bitching about censorship abroad, right? And how we're the bastion of free speech here.

And I'm I'm pretty sure that there's stuff on TV in Germany and in England that Brendan Carr would have his panties in a bunch about here. Um it's super embarrassing on that front. And you just see I mean no matter what story we're covering and you know we're going to talk about the Epstein files, we're going to talk about what's going on with immigration enforcement and ICE. You just like tick down the line of lines of the Constitution and say, "Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. And it's such a huge

opportunity for Democrats to come out and just be on the side of the Constitution, right? Like that these are our core values that speech is protected. And I mean, hiding behind the equal time rule is not going to get you anywhere since Jasmine Crockett has been on Colar. And I'm sure Stephven Colbear would welcome Ken Paxton on to the show could talk about, you know, his legislative career, also his affairs, or John Cornin, who I think would have a much more successful interview, and he doesn't have any skeletons in his closet as far as I know, but he doesn't want to have his feet held to the proverbial

fire over the Trump administration's policies. So, they're not interested in it. But this idea that, and this is why I started with paging Ted Cruz, that there's no slippery slope here, and I hope that Democrats always stand on the side of the Constitution, but there are going to be ruthless people out there that once the Democrats come back into power are saying we should do exactly to them what they did to us. And they wouldn't be wrong for it. And the Republicans that are speaking out at this moment saying like, "Cool it, guys." You know, this is not a third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth,

ninth term for Donald Trump in the hopper, right? Like there's a big chance that we're going to lose the midterm. This is me being them, not me being a Democrat. Lose the midterms. Definitely the House. Maybe a lot of smart people think the Senate's in play. And then 2028, not a foregone conclusion at all, especially if you have JD Vance on top of the ticket. This is a very narrow way to be governing at this particular moment. And it's such a petty small fight. What do you care about 7 and 1/2 minutes of Steven Colbear talking to James Tarico about Christ? I mean,

that's literally what they were talking about. Like that billionaires are bad and that it reduces the importance of Jesus to make him a political issue. That that was the content that they were so afraid of. >> Yeah, I'm now comfortable calling the Trump administration fascist. That's the bad news. The good news is the really [ __ ] stupid fascists. They continue to make these sort of own goals around that just nobody thought to if you type this into an LLM and say what are the risks of the FCC chair

trying to spike an interview with a Democratic Senate candidate. I mean, every LLM would go would come back and say, "No, that's a stupid idea." So, they get their tariff numbers from AI, but they don't bother to run this through. I can't imagine the PR executive or the strategist at the Trump administration saying, "Yeah, Co Bear won't say anything. This won't this won't bring more heat." >> Like Coar isn't even afraid of his own boss at this point. He's like, "I have three months left to go." Like, yolo.

And Colbear is going to I mean his show is ending. If they had just ignored Co Bear, quite frankly, he just wouldn't be nearly as relevant right now because his show does not his show loses a lot of money. And this is a cap, you know, media companies are capitalist, but this comes across as just such um and we're beating a dead I'm beating a dead horse here. So um such extraordinary censorship. And what'll be interesting is to see how many Republicans come out and say this

was a bad move. Cuz it won't be a litmus test of their backbone. It'll be a litmus test of their assessment if whether Trump is losing >> popularity and losing a step. Because I find these guys start to find their testicles when they think there's less and less danger of a blowback from the Trump administration. It's sort of almost like a weakness indicator of whether they think that the Trump fever is about to break. >> Yeah. And it's also an easy one. You know what I mean? Like you don't have to come out against his immigration policy if you just say,

>> "Yeah, I believe in free speech. >> Let Telerico be on Co Bear and air it on a regular network instead of it being a YouTube thing." But it is a good precursor for whatever YouTube show or podcast or whatever Co Bear is going to be uh doing it come May when he no longer has this job anymore. Though, I feel like you should take a few months off at least. Everyone needs needs a break. >> All right, let's take a quick break. Stay with us.

How the DOJ has only released 2% of the Epstein files and what’s still hiding

Welcome back. The Justice Department says it's wrapped its final release of the Epstein files under the transparency law, but new reporting suggests the public has seen maybe just 2% of the total data seized. And already executives, politicians, academics, and even a sitting cabinet secretary are facing the threat of resignations, investigations, and serious reputational damage. Jess, if this is only a fraction of the evidence, why is the DOJ saying they fulfilled the Epstein Files Transparency Act? >> Well, because they're lying. But >> that makes sense.

>> Okay. Is that the end of the show? Because they're lying. >> Don, correct? >> Yeah. Ding, ding, ding. So, the past couple of weeks, you know, I've been very down about this, which I think anyone who's consuming the news as it relates to the Epstein files would be. And you're, you know, horrified and sad and it's so harrowing what happened to these victims and the frustration about so few people caring and there being consequences. And I felt for a couple weeks there that something was going to change. I'm not

saying everybody was going to be prosecuted, but it did feel like there was some momentum and seeing now that the DOJ is saying we're done and you know doing crazy things like releasing all the names involved and then they put out like Janice Joplain on a list who was Epste was 17 when she passed away and you know crowding names together like Joplain and Larry Nasser for instance you realize nothing's going to happen. And I'm getting really sick of seeing headlines from around the world

like last night, you know, breaking French police raid multiple locations in Jeffrey Epstein criminal probe, including the Arab World Institute, right? You're having resignations of people out of foreign governments because they were just in contact with this guy. Kier Starmer may not be the UK prime minister anymore over bad judgment as it relates to putting, you know, someone in uh in government who was linked to him. And I just think like we're not going to do anything. Like Brad Karp doesn't have his job anymore. I saw Casey Wasserman, the you know, the

mega agent stepping down. But it put Pam Bondi's performance last week in a new light to me. Like I actually I thought it was so bad and it was so embarrassing. Not just the stuff everyone's been making fun of, like you got asked a question about a pedophile and you screamed Dow 50,000. Like that's funny in an SNL sense, but I really thought that the image of this attorney general not even turning around to make eye contact with the survivors, women who have endured something that no one

should have to would show Trump that she was not up to this job or that she was just going to be enough of a PR nightmare that she should be gone. But honestly, like looking at it now a few days later, I think it's what Trump wanted. I think that he has made it clear and that Marjgery Taylor Green has been talking about this in interviews that he is the one who has been blocking this and he told her to go out there and be as ridiculous as she needs to be as long as she is stonewalling. And so I have basically no faith in the idea that there will be any

substantive consequences from this or that we're going to find out that much more. Um, so that's I don't want to be Debbie Downer, but that's where I am. >> I'm more hopeful in the sense that I do think there are going to be consequences here, but I think they're going to happen in 2029. And also, I think Democrats and Merrick Garland have to take some responsibility for why these files weren't released earlier, why there haven't been any indictments, why there hasn't been more aggressive push to get to the bottom of what's gone on here during Democratic administrations. What's come to light here is that the Republican party, I mean that that was a

real moment that you just referenced when um Representative Jipal asked the survivors or survivors to stand up and all of them had reached out to the DOJ and none of them uh had their uh overtures. The DOJ has no interest in interviewing these victims. I mean, you'd think that one they would provide insight into crimes and possibly even exonerate some people, but it's clear it's no longer the Department of Justice. It's the Department of Delay and obfuscation. And quite frankly, I think someone did type this into AI and said these in some

form are going to come out in some format. What's the best way to do it? They said confuse the [ __ ] out of everyone. Release a ton of [ __ ] that makes no sense. Then drip it out and create a ton of confusion. And this is what's happened. Um there is like you said just total confusion. This is a total GRU propaganda technique and that is overwhelm and flood the zone with information some true information some false information and make it such that everyone just fed up and shrugs their shoulders. And where I part from the majority of my progressive brothers and

sisters is that I don't believe they should have released the files. I think the way they the Department of Justice and the other agencies who have compiled this data should be communicating with the public is through indictments and saying we are indicting the following people uh for what we believe uh is criminal activity specifically child rape or trafficking trafficking girls or providing infrastructure for the abuse of children. But instead they let out everything and we're all like, "Oh, you know what is what does a spiritual guru

guru think?" And by the way, if a cabinet member purggers himself under oath and is all indignant about having nothing to do with him and then it comes out that he had a lot to do with him, that's criminal activity. But this has worked out perfectly or near perfectly in my view. Perfect is the wrong word. It's been less bad than it should be for the Trump administration because they have weaponized our institutions. our institutions. The Department of Justice is the most poorly named government agency in the world right now. This has nothing to do with justice. It's the Department of Propaganda. It's the

Department of Delay and obuscation. And I do actually think they're doing a really good job because well, while we're focused on what creeps, spiritual guru or wellness longevity doctors are, the government officials or grown men who have engaged in child rape, nothing's going to happen. I am fairly confident that there's enough anger out there that a new attorney general in 28/29 is going to come for some of these people. I think that there's enough thirst out there for blood and some sort of justice

uh that you're going to see something happen. It's just not going to happen for another 3 years. And I don't know what the I don't know what the statute of limitations is on some of these things. >> Yeah. I mean, that's the problem with a lot of it anyway. And I think where some folks that have been implicated have been taking some degree of solace in the situation. But you know it's it's a criminal question but it's also a moral question right about the type of people who should be in leadership positions. And I don't want to paint too broad of a

brush. There are obviously people that are just you know casually like went to a dinner party there. Um, you know, maybe their EAS didn't mention you're going to dinner at a convicted sex offender's house who was soliciting prostitution from a minor, but you know, plenty of people who also were in communication after he was prosecuted again, right, for the stuff that ended him in a jail cell and, you know, murdered. I mean, it was really interesting. Julie K. Brown, the pioneering journalist on this from the Miami Herald, said she doesn't think

that he killed himself. And now that we know about like the erased tapes from the cell and you know that there are entries into the files about dummy bodies coming out different sides of the prisons to distract from the whole situation. There is obviously a lot more to this story and I think that it would be nice if we could get those details and that people could be reading from the same playbook because there's also a ton of bad information in these files to your point about everything getting released or not really everything. um since it's only going to be 2% of it. Um, but you know, I get very tinfoil hat

e about these things and I'm going down a lot of rabbit holes around, you know, the dentist chair that was in his house and the girlfriend that he had, the Bellarusian woman who got into Colombia dental school and, you know, had no business being there. Two administrators I believe have been fired in connection with that. But there's a whole section of the internet that is, you know, talking about how the dental chair was to remove girls teeth so that they wouldn't bite back. You know, like you could go down a number of really scary

paths. Um, I guess I do want to be hopeful though for a second and talk about what's going on in New Mexico. So, you saw how there was an exchange uh in the files about how there might be bodies buried at Epstein Zoro Ranch, which is in New Mexico. That ranch is now owned um by this big MAGA guy who's running for Texas controller. His son works in the White House, by the way. As an aside, he's endorsed by Turning Point at this point. He was refusing to let people come um and look for the bodies on the ranch. Uh but New Mexico

lawmakers last night voted unanimously to approve a truth commission with subpoena power um to probe trafficking and sexual assault at the ranch and that starts effective today. So that testimony actually could lead to prosecution. So I I hope that state lawmakers across the country are taking note of what is possible even without the DOJ wanting to help out. Maybe you'll get some answers when it comes to that. But, you know, I it's all kind of comical, right, when you think like the guy who owns it now is, you know, his

son works in the White House and he's not letting people on there. Like, why wouldn't you let people on there to see if there are dead girls buried on your property? Also, why would you want to live on a property that might have dead girls buried on it? >> Yeah. The the problem with all these rabbit holes is I I worry that they're weapons of mass distraction and that we're all falling into it. So for I thought Ro Kana, Representative Kana summarized it perfectly. He said, open quote to have Janice Joplain who died when Epstein was 17 in the same list as Larry Nasser who went to prison for sexual abuse of hundreds of young women in child pornography with no

clarification of how either was mentioned in the files is absurd. The key to the Epstein files, but the American public wants it all. convicted the first time in 2008. those things and will email with people. That doesn't mean we should be ruining their careers. And all we are doing by creating this like citizen ringlight, I wouldn't even call it journalism, but gossip/ slander is deluding from the focus of the department or what should be the focus of the department of justice. And that is to indict, convict, and imprison criminals. and instead we're trying to instead we're talking about oh this guy this you know this guy should resign or this guy

should or shouldn't be on CVS. I I I think it's I think it's an incredible miscarriage of justice and we are falling into the exact trap that the Trump administration has laid for us and that is the Department of Justice isn't in the business of finding out what emails out you as a total [ __ ] creep. that the next time a an Epstein class of person believes that they can rape children, thinks twice, and says, you know, maybe I shouldn't do this because someone's going to come for me and put me in prison. and that women who are abused like this or girls who are abused think the department of justice has my back. They may be slow but that the arc of the department of justice bends towards truth and justice. This this department has lost so much credibility but they are doing this and to a certain

extent the Trump administration is getting a lot of flack. And instead, we're focused on all of the fun and all of the gossip and oh, this guy, this guy's a creep. Okay? Or this individual had contact with this person. let's talk about it and let's pass judgment on it because from a from a keyboard I'm really [ __ ] virtuous and can judge

other people. This has been in my view the Trump administration if they are trying to create uh diversion, confusion, delusion. We've fallen into that trap. They have played us. >> Now I feel sad because I've been played. But I I just wanted to add well two things. Um, on the Peter Aia front, cuz you, you know, referenced that I do think that there is a difference between people who have been caught up in this and had a few exchanges with him or, you know, flirted a little with Galen

little girls or anything like that, but I think it is going to be very hard and this would turn into a business decision, which Barry Weiss has decided as of now that she is keeping him. that when you turn on the TV and he's talking to you about longevity that you hear echoes in your mind of someone saying, you know, I but we can't tell anyone about who you actually are and that he was with Epstein when his baby was in the ICU, which he wrote about in his book. Like, I I'm not with you on some of these. People have been caught up in

it. The second component about people needing to be convicted of things and to pay some sort of price. of sexual assault and this happened in 2019. And there will be a question this DOJ, you know, isn't going to do anything about it. That was the only thing that kind of stood out on the legal

front from her testimony. I think if somebody has perjured themselves, the Department of Justice has an obligation to indict them or say, "We believe this person perjured themselves." Whether it was, >> you think Todd Blanch is going to be like, "Pam, you've gone too far." Now, >> look, and that might be that'll probably be a a different Department of Justice. Um, when it comes to someone like uh Peter Aia, the department, and this is the gray zone, the Department of Justice might feel that if a medical doctor who's been licensed and accredited by

certain medical boards, do they have an obligation to inform them of what might have been criminal activity? Look, President Trump was found guilty of 34 felony counts and he was found civily liable for sexual abuse. I believe that warrants additional investigation by the Department of Justice for what appears to be evidence that he may have engaged in more criminal activity, which I believe gives the Department of Justice a fact pattern where they probably want to further investigate the president and his activities

with respect to somebody just being an abysmal human being who is also providing medical advice and it's handled themselves incredibly poorly and has probably no business giving other people medical advice and having a big platform. And my view is the following litmus test. Is this person

guilty or is there evidence that warrants government resources to file a criminal indictment against this person? That's it. And as much fun as it is to call these people out deservedly for what incredible [ __ ] hypocrats hypocrites they are. I mean, Secretary Lutnik, my view is he's such an idiot that he committed a crime trying to cover up what wasn't a crime. If he had just said, "Really poor judgment. This guy was my neighbor. He seemed like a baller. I thought he was wellconed. Me and my kids went to his island. Just

What is the Department of Justice in the business of and what are they not in the business of? >> I totally agree with you. Um, I think it's a real question also about our quality of journalists and how few people trust anyone in any sort of position of power, whether it's government or the quote

unquote mainstream media. And that was part of the drive for getting all these files out here. But the problem is you have, you know, citizen journalists or just anyone with an access with access to an ex account or whatever whatever social media channel you happen to be on and then that becomes Bible to you and it splinters us even more. Um, but there's no question that these survivors deserve a lot more than they are getting and probably than they are ever to get. Um, in terms of even recognition for

what they went through and we should make sure that the focus always stays on that cuz it it's it's just terrible. and to see the pain in their eyes and to listen to these interviews. Um, it's it's sickening and it it's just really sad. I think a decent opening statement or confirmation for a nominee for the next attorney general, hopefully under a Democratic administration, would be, "I am laser-like focused on bringing justice to the victims of Jeffrey Epstein and criminally indicting the

people who engage in criminal activity, who engaged in child rape, provided infrastructure for it, trafficked it, and that is it. That is where I'm going to focus all my resources and that is it. And if you're looking for titillating information on what a [ __ ] creep someone is, that's not why I'm here. >> Yeah. A professionalization of the office uh would be good. >> People don't realize, and this goes to just how much damage social media has done. There are two ways you don't get

chained by the community and cast out into the darkness and get eaten alive by bears and wolves. And that is one through either strength or wisdom. And one unfortunate means of somehow granting wisdom in a very fake, superficial, but what seems to be increasingly important, I don't know, vehicle is the social media algorithms give you likes and attention and money if you feed into the algorithm. And finding somebody famous who is in these files for whatever reason is going to get you is the algorithms love it. It's embarrassing

for them. It creates conversation. It creates likes. It creates another 50, 80, 100 bucks from AdSense on YouTube. And it elevates information that in my view often times does nothing but polarize us, divide us. And here's how we end up with a Vance Teal presidency, which is if Vance is is president, be clear, Teal's not going to be his vice president. He'll actually be the president. Vance will be the VP again. This is how it happens on the left. We just [ __ ] attack each other. Casey Wasserman, that's who's got to resign.

That that who's that's the guy flirtatious emails with Gelain Maxwell before before Epstein is ever convicted of anything. That's the guy who's whose career we're ruining. That's the one who pays the price. >> You saw um that great image. I think it was New Yorker did it. Um, with all the red arrows that point in one direction and then blue arrows are all pointing in different directions and at each other as a, you know, metaphor for how Republicans do politics and how

Democrats do politics. And we are the ultimate circular firing squad every time. >> I'm triggered. I'm totally triggered here because and whenever I talk about the epsin by the when I when I think I was summarizing something you had said and I said that if somebody this individual I said something along the lines of this person should be criminally or indicted and pursued for sex with underage women.
