The future of ICE

Welcome back. Before we go, Congress is deadlocked over funding the Department of Homeland Security and the fight over ICE reform is unfolding as immigration enforcement continues expanding. Senate Democrats want body cameras and ID rules for agents. Republicans say ICE funding is already secured through 2028 and warn the shutdown is instead hitting FEMA and TSA. Jess, who do you think blinks first and how long uh can this drag on? >> I think it could go on for a while. I mean, especially because it's concentrated in DHS. It does not seem like Democrats really any of them except like Federman

uh really has much appetite for compromising. Um especially on some of these key planks. It'll be interesting if Republicans, you know, get it together and come back and say these are the two or three proposals that we can live with. I mean, even some very conservative senators um have said, you know, definitely open to body cams. Masks seem to be where they're drawing the line. Like Tom Hman even said, "We don't want to have to be wearing masks, but people's families are getting doxed." Um I'm think that there's probably a correlation between what these agents are doing and the fact that

people are coming after them. Um I am not in any way justifying it. I think that, you know, doxing is unacceptable. people's families need to be, you know, kept safe and protected. Um, but there's probably more, as with everything that we agree upon than we don't. Um, but I think this one could go for a while. Um, lot of agencies affected, TSA, FEMA, Coast Guard, Secret Service, um, ICE, obviously, US Customs and Border Patrol, but it is funded through the end of the

Trump administration because of the reconciliation bill. they got an extra $75 billion. So, it's a bit of a a false choice talking point, I guess, to say, you know, defund ICE or we're going to defund ICE. You can't. That money has gone out the door. But I wanted to frame this in a way that you actually did around the Epstein files and even what we were talking about with the FCC overreach. Again, the Trump administration is taking major hits because of these very unpopular policy positions. So, they're 100% on the back

foot when it comes to ICE and immigration enforcement. Trump just hit new lows in four major polls, Quinnipak, Yahoo, NBC, and the AP. He's doing way worse than Joe Biden was. If the election were held today and the Ras Mucin pollster, who's a right-leaning pollster, even said this, Joe Biden would win. He's now at minus 27 with independence. You cannot win an election at minus 27 with independents, bleeding non-ol support. He was even down two points with white voters. And Democrats haven't won white voters since 1964. So I'm not saying that that poll, it was

a Quantis poll. It's a good pollster that we would win white voters, but that's crazy. And now 58% of voters under 30 disapprove of the job Trump's doing. So, every swing category, Latinos, especially Latino men, young voters, has swung back. And I think you can draw a direct line between what is going on in America's streets and especially in Minneapolis and this change. And we're always looking for a silver lining or something to be hopeful about. And we were talking about this um last week uh with your buddy uh Jeff

Sonnenfeld and his new book and how can you push back and the idea of collective action. The people of Minneapolis have given us a road map. They have shown that you can push back effectively. It's a tragedy what happened with Renee Good and Alex Patty. Of course, I want to talk about that a bit more in terms of what's going on with the ICE. Um, but they will back down if you show up and you peacefully protest and you tell them that this isn't all right. This isn't American. This is not how we do things here. Tom Hman announcing that the surge

is over. A small security force is going to remain. That's a win for our side. And I think that we should recognize that and know that it is going to take every one of us who feels, you know, distraught, disturbed, incensed, angry, livid over what's going on, that you may have to show up for a protest or two, that you may have to push back in any way that you can, that you may have to resist and unsubscribe. Um, but that you can make change and you're not powerless. >> Yeah, I agree with you. I think that they picked the wrong state, right? And

I do think it's mobilized people. And to be bereft and believe that we're the first generation to face this type of behavior or a dark time, it just doesn't understand or or really have any historical context. There we have absolutely faced worse predicaments than this. Whether it's civil wars, world wars, plagues, interning Japanese people, you know, we civil rights violations, not mentioning the word AIDS because you think it's such, you know, gay people are such an abomination. We have we have faced very

big crises and every time Americans have uh equaled the moment and the fear this time is that we have become so fat and happy and so prosperous that we take our institutions and our rights for granted. And I don't think that's happening here. And I think the people of Minnesota have kind of, as you've said, have kind of provided a great example and sort of led the way here. The trust in government, it's just so upsetting. Just 17% of Americans now say they trust the government in Washington to do what is right. Just about always is 2% and most of the time is 15%. Now get this. That's

17% versus in 1958 73% of Americans trusted the federal government to do the right thing. always most of the time. Uh by 1980, post Vietnam and Watergate, only a quarter of Americans expressed a high level of trust, but it's still double what it is now. Uh as the economy grew in the late '9s, trust in government also rose. It also rose after 9/11 and then fell after 2008. Uh twothirds of Americans report having not very much or no trust in Congress. So there's just a lack again of faith in our in our institutions. You said

something earlier in the show I want to double click on and that is quite frankly unless we i.e. Democrats [ __ ] this up and we are famous at snatching defeat from the jaws of victory sea above start ship posting each other instead of actually focusing on the real adversary here but you had said something it looks as if we're going to take back Congress. you had said that now there's some credible pollsters specifically the predictions markets saying there's not a non-zero probability that we actually take the Senate. Do you have any thoughts on that? And you can be can you be more

specific about which Senate seats might be in play that weren't before? >> Yeah, I mean so the ones that I I feel really good about uh North Carolina um with Rory Cooper uh running there it I don't know. I'm so conflicted about what's going on in the main primary. Um, but it does feel like Susan Collins is more vulnerable than she is usually. And I was someone who thought that there was a chance that she was going to lose uh 6 years ago and she won by double digits. Um, but it does feel like the mood is we

need a change. Janet Mills, who's the current governor running for Senate in the Democratic primary, had a brutal, awesome ad um about, you know, how concerned Susan Collins has been for decades and how she really does nothing about it. And she also, like many politicians, said, you know, not going to serve for some absurd amount of time. I think it was just two terms, but she's been in there now, I think, like 30 years. Um, so that's pretty hard-hitting. But it seems like Graham Platner the you know the lefty candidate in there has a lot of enthusiasm um on

the ground and that's the you know this fight between the younger generation and the old guard is definitely coming into play. Um Ohio is really interesting. I love shared Brown. He is you know the workingclass warrior uh that we all uh adore and you know probably the only candidate who I think could win that Ohio seat back. um linking this to what we were just talking about with Epstein. The guy who he's running against, John Hustad, I think that's how you pronounce it, apparently took $100,000 from Epstein. And now Sherid Brown is featuring that in his ads. And that'll be interesting to see. I think it's the

only one in the country, at least um on the congressional or Senate level, where we're talking about a potential Epstein angle um to it, and we'll see how unpopular that actually makes you. Um, so I think Ohio is, you know, it's a red state now, but Chered Brown is the guy who could do it. Um, you know, Texas I still think is a total pipe dream, um, to be able to do that. And people are really interested in what's going on in Iowa. Um, I was, you know, Rob Sand who's running for governor, feeling good. Nathan Sage just dropped out of the Democratic primary on the Senate

side and endorsed Josh Turk, uh, who is a very cool and interesting candidate. It has an amazing story. Um, so you know, those are just some places I guess that I'm paying attention, but it is the first time that I've felt like there could be a blue wave. You know, Brian and I have been having those conversations like every young, you know, set of parents. Where would it be better to live, right? Like >> where would it be better to raise kids? I know that you're a big proponent of the Florida model. Um, I couldn't live in Florida under a Governor Dantis. I I just couldn't get there. But it was the

first time that I even allowed myself to say, well, like what if David Jolly did win, right? Like what what if it is such a big blue wave that you have a Democrat in the governor's mansion in Florida? Does that change calculus about being in a state like that? And I think that it does. I I'm not I'm not predicting that we have that big of a wave, but those conversations don't feel insane to people when you're flipping Trump plus 25 seats, right? in states like Texas and Louisiana. Um, you know, the map is

getting bluer and it's lighting up brighter and Democrats at this moment have the enthusiasm on our side showing up for these special elections. We're going to show up on election day. The question will be, you know, what Trump on the trail will do. I happen to think it's just going to make us show up more because he's like that big flashing sign that we just can't stand. and midterm voters um on the right don't tend to be as passionate as certainly the party that's trying to get back into power. Um but that's I guess my overview.

>> So you mentioned Florida and obviously that's I'm I'm a resident of Florida. What do you think of a matchup between Lieutenant Colonel Vinman who's announced he's running in the Democratic primary for the special election seat for Rubio seat versus the AG appointed to Rubio Senate seat by Governor Dantis? Do you think Vinman has a shot? >> I have not looked at polling on that. I think the Vinman's um both of them are very compelling characters. I don't know. It's a tough one because in a lot of ways I think that they're or

he's representative of, you know, a conversation about democracy and the rule of law and >> like a lot of those lines of argumentation that we didn't win on previously if you do you know what I'm saying? So >> that part is tough for me. Um, but ethically, morally speaking, like the kind of person that I would like to see uh going to Washington. Yeah, 100%. I think that's great. But, you know, it's interesting to see Dantis, who was

really on the outs with Trump, obviously challenging him in the last primary, Meatball Ron, I think is what he called him. Apparently, he was playing golf with Trump just a few days ago. And you can see a move to bring the coalition back together. Trump is not picking as many fights internally as he was, except if you speak out about the Epstein files. Like he's endorsing everybody in these primaries instead of picking sides. Um, and I think Ashley Moody will definitely appeal to a lot of normies.

She's an establishment favorite kind of person. And there are still a lot of Republicans out there that are begging for a world in which there's a return to normaly. I think just as people underestimate Governor Nuome, I think they underestimate Governor DeSantis. I think you learn a lot running a campaign. You have an infrastructure that could be fired up pretty easily. He comes across I think he's I think he comes across as more of a leader than either Rubio or Vance. Um I I I would not count him out. And with respect to Inman, I think he's an American hero. I follow Florida politics semi- closely.

Unfortunately, I think it's going to be an impeachment nostalgia campaign, and I don't think that's what Flityians care about. I think unfortunately that race is going to be won or lost on boring [ __ ] like uh insurance, which a third of Florida homeowners can't get right now, and HOA fees that have skyrocketed and seniors are having to give up their condos because of regulation. I mean, it's basically you have millions and millions of people in Florida who move down there thinking they'd spend the rest of their lives down there who are having to sell their homes and leave because of uh the insurance market has

totally turned against them and because of um HOA fe I mean it's just it sounds I'm bored talking about it but I think that is what's going to >> well that's what wins elections right in your day-to-day life. >> Yeah. I think there'll be a lot of great ads about Lieutenant Colonel Linman and his his uniform and talking about how brave he is. And that's not what that's not what's going to turn people out. People are going to think, "Okay, >> well, it's a great side dish, but the entree has to be >> improving to lower your cost of living to make sure you have the insurance that

you need." I was actually we last year I interviewed David Jolly for the pod who's running on the Democratic side uh for >> governor and he kept emphasizing that because you know he's a Republican turned Democrat and that's the story that people like us always want to talk about like you know when did it hit you that the Republicans are so evil right that you had to come over to the other side and he was like I've got a plan to lower people's taxes right to make sure that you can afford a home like that's what people are showing up for it is a luxury to be a quote unquote democracy

voter unless you can connect the dots, which I think that we can, between the assault on democracy and your cost of living cuz that is available through the tariffs and all of these abuses with what's going on with immigration enforcement because immigrants make us more prosperous. They make the and they make the country better. They are a net contributor, right? They are the ones who are actually paying more into the system. But you're you're totally right. will be paying attention to the campaign as it uh rolls out. But Vinman is a hero who needs an insurance plan. >> There you go.

>> Like for actual insurance, not like cuz something's going to happen to it. >> All right, before we go, if you're watching us on YouTube, please make sure you hit subscribe. That's all for this episode. Thank you for listening to Raging Moderates.

item.title: Is Trump’s DOJ “playing us”?
item.description: Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov break down the implications of the Epstein Files that the DOJ has — and hasn’t — released, on Raging Moderates.
